title: 105_hr4174
content: Section 1 of the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 is amended to allow expedited consideration of certain proposed rescissions. The President can propose rescinding budget authority or repealing targeted tax benefits, with a special message to Congress including a draft bill specifying the amounts to be rescinded. These funds cannot be proposed for rescission again under this section. The President can propose rescinding budget authority or repealing targeted tax benefits through a special message to Congress, including a draft bill specifying the amounts to be rescinded. A Deficit Reduction Account can be created, with a limit on the total rescissions in that bill. Targeted tax benefits can only be proposed for repeal within a 20-calendar-day period after the enactment of the provision. The President can propose rescinding budget authority by sending a special message and draft bill to Congress. The message must specify the amount, the account or department affected, reasons for rescission, and the estimated effects. The President can propose rescinding budget authority by sending a special message and draft bill to Congress, specifying the amount, account affected, reasons for rescission, and estimated effects. The special message must include the fiscal, economic, and budgetary effect of the proposed rescission, along with all relevant facts and considerations. Additionally, for the repeal of targeted tax benefits, specific information is required as outlined in subparagraphs (C), (D), and (E). Before the second legislative day after receiving a special message, the majority or minority leader of the House must introduce the draft bill. If not, any member can introduce it on the third legislative day. The bill will be referred to the appropriate committee, which must report it without substantive revision and with or without recommendation within a specified timeframe. The bill must be reported by the appropriate committee within seven legislative days of receiving a special message. If the committee fails to do so, they will be discharged, and the bill will be placed on the calendar for consideration. Members of the House can move to strike proposed rescissions or repeals with support from 49 other Members during the process. The bill must be reported by the appropriate committee within seven legislative days of receiving a special message. If the committee fails to do so, they will be discharged, and the bill will be placed on the calendar for consideration. A vote on final passage of the bill shall be taken in the House of Representatives on or before the close of the 10th legislative day. Debate on a bill in the House of Representatives under this section is limited to 4 hours, divided equally between supporters and opponents. Appeals on procedural decisions related to the bill are decided without debate. Amendments to the motion or reconsideration of the vote are not allowed. Consideration of a bill under this section in the House of Representatives is governed by the House Rules. Rescission bills cannot be considered under suspension of the rules or a special rule. Bills transmitted to the Senate are referred to the appropriate committee, which must report the bill without substantive revision within seven legislative days. During consideration of a bill in the Senate, any Member can move to strike proposed rescissions or repeals with support from 14 others. Amendments must reduce the Deficit Reduction Account if the program was identified in it. During Senate consideration of a bill, a motion to proceed is privileged and not debatable. Debate on the bill and related motions shall not exceed 10 hours, divided between the majority and minority leaders. The Senate limits debate on a bill to 10 hours, divided between majority and minority leaders. Appeals are limited to 1 hour, divided between the mover and bill manager. The minority leader controls time in opposition. Amendments and divisions are generally prohibited. No amendments allowed to bills under this section in the House or Senate. Division of question not permitted in the House or Senate. Motion to suspend subsection not allowed in either House. Budget authority proposed for rescission must be available for obligation after rejection of the bill. Targeted tax benefits can be repealed as per special message to Congress. The section outlines that any targeted tax benefit can be repealed through a special message to Congress. Definitions for terms like 'appropriation Act' and 'legislative day' are also provided. The text discusses the amendment of Section 904 of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to include sections 1012 and 1017. Additionally, there are conforming amendments made to sections 1011 and 1014 of the Act. Section 1014 of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to remove references to reservations. Section 1015(a) is also amended to remove mentions of establishing a reserve. Section 1017 is amended to remove references to rescission bills. Section 1017 of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to remove mentions of rescission bills. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to limit debate on debatable motions or appeals related to an impoundment resolution to 1 hour, divided between the mover and the resolution manager. The amendment removes mentions of rescission bills and specifies that the minority leader or designee will control time in opposition to motions or appeals favored by the resolution manager. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to limit debate on debatable motions or appeals related to an impoundment resolution. Amendments include removing certain sentences and paragraphs in section 1012. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to expedite consideration of certain proposed rescissions and targeted tax benefits.
